title: The Unspun Verse
tagline: In a world that demands silence, one woman dares to write her own song.
themes: The Conflict Between Public Duty and Private Voice
Poetry as Subversion and Secret Language
The Commodification of Women in Marriage Alliances
The Domestic Sphere as a Site of Quiet Rebellion

chapters.title: The Dream of Light and Ash

story: Write a scene where Aelia secretly teaches another young woman in the household to read lyric poetry, using the rhythms of weaving as a code.
Create a subplot from Lucius's perspective: he discovers a political threat that mirrors Aelia's personal rebellion, forcing him to question his own rigid worldview.
Imagine a clandestine literary salon Aelia discovers, run by freedwomen in the Subura. Detail a meeting where a new, dangerous poem is shared.
Write the 'lost' poem Aelia writes about her marriage, using the metaphor of the Tyrian purple dye—its beauty, its cost, and its stain.
technical: Build a text analysis tool that compares the linguistic patterns in Aelia's internal monologues (provided in seed chapters) with actual Catullan verse, highlighting thematic and metric echoes.

Design an interactive map of a Roman domus (house) keyed to chapters, where clicking on rooms (tablinum, lararium, etc.) reveals excerpts of text where that space is charged with gender/power dynamics.

council: Sappho of Lesbos (for lyric intimacy and female voice)
Tacitus (for political tension and the psychology of repression)
Charlotte Brontë (for the interior life of a constrained woman)
James Joyce (for stream of consciousness and the subversion of epic tradition)

cover_prompt: A young noblewoman in a classical Roman stola, her back to an opulent marble courtyard, secretly inscribing poetry with a stylus onto a wax tablet concealed in her lap, while a formal betrothal ceremony unfolds in the blurred background, her act of quiet defiance the only point of sharp focus. The scene is set at dusk in a lavish domus atrium, with hanging ivy and a faint, ghostly echo of Sappho's fragmented verses subtly etched into the texture of the marble columns and mosaic floor, suggesting a hidden language beneath the surface of sanctioned life. In the atmospheric style of John William Waterhouse, with the poetic realism and mythological gravity of Lawrence Alma-Tadema's classical interiors. Book cover framing, centered composition with a dramatic low-angle view that elevates the subject, making her private act monumental.
